abstract.p: Androgen excess (hyperandrogenism) is a common endocrine disorder affecting women of reproductive age. The potential causes of androgen excess in women include polycystic ovary syndrome, congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), adrenal tumors, and racial disparity among many others. During pregnancy, luteoma, placental aromatase deficiency, and fetal CAH are additional causes of gestational hyperandrogenism. The present report reviews the various phenotypes of hyperandrogenism during pregnancy and its origin, pathophysiology, and the effect of hyperandrogenism on the fetal developmental trajectory and offspring consequences.

Precis: Adverse in-utero environment has been linked to adaptive vs. maladaptive programming of the developing fetus. This manuscript reviews the various hyperandrogenic states and the impact of gestational hyperandrogenic environment in programming offspring pathology. In addition, this manuscript identifies gaps in linking human hyperandrogenic states with offspring pathology, and points to the potential for androgen to serve as a biomarker in predicting offspring disease outcomes.
